awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Collaborative proposal: Engineering increased activity of cutinase toward poly(ethyleneterephthalate) for recycling of plastic
awd_abstract_narration:
The environmental consequences of plastic solid waste are serious. The problem continues to increase as we diversify and expand plastic use and applications. The most significant example of this problem is the rate that plastics are accumulating in oceans, lakes and rivers. The most widely used plastic is polyethylene terephthalate, or PET. PET is used in the manufacture of bottles, polyester fabrics, and food trays. Production levels are estimated to be over 50 million tons per year. This project will attempt to develop an efficient enzyme for the degradation of PET. High school students will be engaged in summer research opportunities. Undergraduate and graduate students will also be involved in the project. These opportunities will help develop a STEM workforce.

Recently, several groups discovered enzymes that catalyze PET hydrolysis under mild conditions. Unfortunately, these enzymes are too slow and too unstable for practical use. Protein engineering to increase their catalytic efficiency is a potential solution.  The project tests a new approach for engineering enzymes to act on insoluble substrates. This approach recognizes that the interaction between an enzyme and an insoluble substrate is complex and involves an extended binding site. The enzyme must pull the chain from the bulk polymer, position the ester group for hydrolysis, and allow the polymer substrate to slide within the binding site for repeated hydrolysis of the chain. Previous attempts to increase the activity of enzymes toward insoluble substrates have met with limited success. The proposed large-area-mutagenesis (LAM) methodology to be implemented in this program is a systematic strategy for engineering enzymes for insoluble synthetic polymer substrates. The approach will: 1) establish the size of the binding region in cutinase that influences its catalytic activity toward PET; 2) optimize the shape of the extended binding region for PET, 3) increase the thermal stability of the enzyme for use above the glass transition temperature of PET, where chain mobility is higher, allowing better access of the enzyme to the polymer substrate. The results of this program will be the engineering of an efficient, stable enzyme with increased catalytic activity of at least 100-fold that may be suitable for commercial PET recycling, which is an essential step to reducing plastic pollution. This project is supported jointly by the Cellular and Biochemical Engineering  Program in CBET/ENG and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in CHE/MPS.

por.por_cntn:
Overview - Commodity plastics offer comfort and convenience but have also created environmental problems. Since only 10% of plastics are recycled in the US, they accumulate in landfills and pollute our waterways. Most recycling of plastic is ‘downcycling’ to lower value materials that cannot be recycled a second time. Better recycling can contribute to solving the environmental problems of plastics. Polyesters, for example, poly(ethylene terephthalate), PET, can be hydrolyzed to their building blocks, which could be used to resynthesize high-quality plastic for repeated recycling. Enzymatic recycling of PET possesses several advantages over chemical and physical recycling methods, but, currently-identified PET degrading enzymes are hampered by insufficient productivity for commercial use.

Summary of outcomes - This work was successful in improving the productivity of LCC catalyzed PET hydrolysis through semi-rational redesign. A library of 53 LCC variants was screened for initial activity on PET film. Twelve variants were then down selected and assessed for their ability to reach ≥ 90% depolymerization as a function of time and temperature (55, 62, and 70 °C) under industrially relevant enzyme and solids loading conditions. A novel quadruple variant of LCC, engineered with two substitutions in the active site region and a disulfide bridge was identified as a top performer that converts 90% of PET to terephthalic acid (TPA) in 17 ± 3.4 hours. While its activity at 70 °C was comparable to previously reported, high-performing variants, it has the unique characteristic of completely hydrolyzing PET to TPA within a broad temperature window (55, 62 and 70°C). Linear correlation analyses between LCC-variant stabilities and activities, obtained through different assays, highlight the detriment of solely relying on initial kinetics measurements to evaluate the performance of PET-hydrolyzing enzymes, as ≥ 90% depolymerization was not well predicted by initial rate measurements or thermal stability measurements. The findings herein present an extensive profile of LCC-variant activities that enhance our understanding of enzyme behavior with respect to industrial conditions, temperature, and incubation time.

Intellectual Merit - This work provides a deeper understanding of engineered LCC performance for PET hydrolysis by designing, expressing, and analyzing a series of LCC variants based on mutations known to improve or affect activity in homologous enzymes. The addition of an engineered disulfide bridge, CC, was used to increase thermal stability of recombinant LCC and offset potential destabilizing effects of mutations in the binding pocket. Substitutions were implemented combinatorially to observe how accumulation of mutations affects performance. Activity was assayed by 96-well initial kinetics measurements and by total depolymerization over longer term PET recombinant enzyme incubations monitored by pH stat.  Systematic analysis by pH stat proved highly informative as it was used to determine the total extent of PET hydrolysis, productivity, hours to 90% degradation and maximum productivity. The extent of correlations between initial kinetics determined by UV absorbance, pH stat, and important performance parameters such as time to 90% degradation and productivity at 12 h provided key insights into the predictive value of short-term assays vs. long term incubations.  The performance of variant enzymes for PET hydrolysis was determined at three temperatures, between 55 and 70 °C, to understand the extent that Topt was variant-dependent and the corresponding tolerances to changes in temperature in reactors. 

Most important findings - From a library of LCC variants engineered based on substitutions known to affect PET-degrading activity in homologous enzymes, we discovered a quadruple LCC variant (H218S-F243T-D238C-S283C) that hydrolyzes 90% of amorphous PET microparticles in 17.0 ± 3.4 h at 70 oC under industrially-relevant conditions. Furthermore, this variant catalyzes high PET-to-monomer conversions at a temperature range of 55-72 oC. The real-time PET-hydrolysis profiles of 12 LCC variants were obtained using a pH stat, and linear correlation analysis of the overall PET degradation ability obtained from this study was compared to initial kinetics, stability, and binding pocket hydrophobicity, which showed that many commonly used high-throughput activity screens do not reliably predict enzyme performance under commercially-relevant enzyme concentrations and solids-loading. Improving enzyme screening methodologies, such as incorporating high-crystallinity PET substrates, optimizing reaction conditions, and extending assay durations, will be crucial for identifying variants capable of achieving high PET conversion efficiencies.
